div.p: Greetings. I received the two letters you sent, dear brother, as well as those you included from Augsburg, and I thank you very much for this service. However, since there is nothing in your letters that requires a response, I will save whatever time I would have spent writing for both of us. I am sending my brief response to Brentius's lengthy and fluid Recognition; I hope that, if I do not benefit readers much or at least somewhat, I do not harm anyone. I pray to the Lord to bless my labors.

I would gladly hear your judgment on this work of mine. You will find errors in many places; the corrector is indeed a poor corrector; but they can be corrected from the context. I have added some errors at the end... I have collected, etc.
The assembly at Baden is only just beginning today.

May the Lord, who alone can avert evil from us, turn it to good! Never have I been more anxious than now; there are many things that frighten me; but in the meantime, I am strong in the Lord, whom I sincerely pray to have mercy on us. It is amazing how those bloodthirsty men are eager to rush to their own destruction.
Farewell and diligently pray to the Lord for our peace.
Greet the brothers in Winterthur and the mayor, as well as your brother, your son, your sister, and your nephews.
When you have leisure, write back.

This might be the last book I send to you; for I hope the Lord will soon grant me rest. But I rejoice that I have shared with you all the books I have published in my ministry, and have given them to you as to my most closely connected brother; you will kindly appreciate my most willing intention.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Ambrosius Blarer in Winterthur, my most esteemed lord and dearest brother.
